title: Future European activities and funding perspectives for SMEs
segmentation: So good afternoon, thanks for sticking around.
My name is Stefano Bethel and I work as a scientific project officer for the European Commission.

What I will do in the next 20 minutes or so is give you an overview of the kind of funding, opportunities and perspective that exist for small and medium enterprises in the last year of framework program #7.
So as you probably know, this program has work programs that are being revised on a 2 year cycle, so the framework program lasts seven years.
So we have a work program coming up that covers only the very last year.
So the official work program will be published sometime.

In July, so as of today, there is nothing official to communicate on this subject, so you should not expect for me to either quote the exact text of the work program, nor to give you dates, nor to give you budget information.
However, what I'll try to do, I'll try to do the next best thing from your point of view to try to be moderately useful for you and give you some general direction of.
You want you can expect to happen and those opportunities to be so OK that I already said so.

My discussion will be so if the framework program is a very large program, so there will be, for example, funding opportunities for SMS who are working in embedded components who are working in networking.
But that's not what I will be talking about, so I will be restricting my discussion to the kind of opportunities that.
Are important for SMS.
They work in data intensive environment like I would imagine many of you are OK, so one domain of activity where.

You can expect funding is in the domain of content analytics, so a lot of the work that was discussed yesterday and today has to do with situations where the data that you have is already structured according to a certain format.
In many cases, fairly clean, so the case, for example, where you get your data from a sensor, there is no ambiguity whatsoever on the meaning of any particular reading.
There is perhaps ambiguity or uncertainty about the correctness of the record, but certainly not on its meaning.

There are other domains where this is not true, so if you're receiving as input, for example, a very large library of video, or a speech or audio, then the events of interest to you have to be actually extracted from those inputs, so there's going to be some opportunity for those of you who work in this domain to work on exactly that problem.
Also, exploit the whatever social and collective intelligence can be brought to bear on the tasks.
So sometimes in fact, often and increasingly so.
These materials do not live in a vacuum.
They live in a social medium where various forms of interactions happen that can be exploited in order to make sense of that content.

Also, work will be invited on anything having to do with the semantic interpretation of things like sentiment events, so things that happen in space and time that have to be identified and reconstructed as such, and very importantly, because.
Europe is a multilingual environment analysis and techniques that work not only across media.
So for example, speech and text or video and text, but also across languages.
So this we put under the label content analytics.
So for those of you who work on machine translation.

There will also be important opportunities, so here again, the goal is to use large data resources to develop high quality translation that is suitable for publication, so perhaps not in a completely automatic fashion.
There's like power tools for translators, and to devise mechanisms so we see this is a similar theme to the previous slide for the autonomous Collection of human feedback so.
There is a translator working in this environment.
She translates from a language to another one.
The translation system gives a possible option and she decides that a different options is in fact more appropriate.
So something has been learned by this interaction that the system should be able to capture.
Also, these systems should be able to handle everyday language, so it should not be assumed that you will receive complete sentences grammatically well formed in a controlled vocabulary.
So everyday language has all kind of disfluencies interruptions, Gergel expressions that that should be handled by such systems.
An important point that builds on the work, for example that the guys from Port dial to were talking about yesterday.
It will continue to be important to think about the infrastructural aspect of developing web or enterprise repositories for translation resources so.

This is not necessarily the work of the linguist, it is the work of the engineer who must make sure that whatever the linguist needs is being managed in an inductor, industrial scale, or at the scale required for the particular language task.
Now we will also be supporting work on spoken and multi modal.

Interactions so again, just like in the previous case, in addition to controlled language in completely stable acoustic conditions, systems will be asked to deal with conversational speech and possibly noisy environment also.
Work is invited on exploiting phenomena that are social in nature.

So oftentimes so because the eventual goal of these applications is to support various applications, it is important to be able to recognize and generate social cues, so it's not just to generate language that is correct, but language that is appropriate under the circumstances, or they not, only that it is not only that is appropriate.
But it is readily understood and perceived to be appropriate by human users.
And again this is for deployement on various types of environments that you're free to choose.
So from the traditional desktop but also on mobile devices or in games environment.
And again an important requirement for these exercises that you should be able to organize your work in such a way that appropriate web or enterprise repositories are being.
Generated that can deal with that kind of work.
So finally be 'cause this is the last year of the framework program.
There is a need for taking a look ahead and try to get off.
Will be in the future so.

Again, to be very blunt, essentially to start making plans for what the Horizon 2020 program in this particular domain should be concerned with, and this will require some Rd mapping work probably supported in the form of a support action to how to make plans for platforms that could host multi language datasets.
And again here we go back to the plans that we were discussing yesterday and processing tools or basic services.
Now moving on to data analytics.
So here the problems that were central in our program for.
The years 2011 and 2012 will remain central, specifically, cause the growth of data as it has been pounded into you over the last two days, has not relented.
In fact has.
Picked up phase in the last few years so we will still be looking for novel algorithms for high volume or real time analytics.

So if any of you especially small industries so small companies are often very close to some specific problems where some specific form of optimizations that may elude a more more abstract thinking scientific environment are in a good position to do this.
So here the second bullet point is actually.
Somehow novel compared to the previous work program.
So what we ask you to look at is what are the relative growth trends for various types of data.
So if you look around and in fact if you are a small company you probably have a business requirement staring at you in the face.
You will see that there are certain data types that are growing more rapidly than others and so in that case again.
Every abundance creates a scarcity, so if there is an abundance of the new type of data, there is a scarcity of the intelligence needed to process it.
So a very good example of this there.
Is there a number of examples, so this is obvious in those cases where there are structured and in many cases industrial processes that generate that.
So I think this is an example that came up several times between yesterday and today.
The first human genome was sequenced at a cost of 1 billion dollars, and today we are.
Approximately at the $1000 point.
So what does that mean?
That you know if you could produce one genome every 10 years, 10 years ago today you can produce 40,000 complete human genomes in a year, and this is only going to get worse.
So that is a specific type of data where you know that you're going to have more data you can interpret.
In fact, I was reading a statistics the other day that claimed that today.
It is far more expensive to analyze the human genome than it is to sequence it, so identify bottlenecks after nature.
Another example yesterday, I don't know if you have looked into the news.
Google made an announcement that by September they intend to cover.
They tend to do produce 3D models for urban environments, covering up to 300 million people.
So you're going to have.
All the major cities in the United States expressed as complete 3D models.
We have companies in Europe that do the same, so there is a company in Sweden for example.
There was recently acquired by Apple and rumor has it that Apple intends to do exactly the same thing.
Replaced Google Maps with its own and have it in 3D.
OK, So what is the option of that?
The option is that there is an immense amount of 3D information that is coming our way, and so there's going to be a need to interpret it.
So if your business is selling glass.

You may have an interest in knowing how many square meters of windows are there in the city of Berlin, because you want to have a ballpark figure of what your business might be if you move to billing so the data is growing, it is at that time we don't have today the ability to understand 3D at the scale with which we are able to understand, for example, text to solve.
There is an obvious bottleneck there.
Another important one.
So before we were talking about data streams.
So again, there are billions of devices that are coming online network there are going to transmit sensor data.
So again, who is going to analyze all these sensor data?
So general form of advice is look around and in fact if you are in the business, reflect on the dynamics, the data dynamics of your business and ask yourself where are the bottlenecks.
So if you can motivate a bottleneck, we're happy to support you in shattering the bottling another form of work that we will support.
Is non traditional database management system.
So here the labels that you may be familiar with.
Our labels like no SQL or new SQL.
So if you have a design for a new architecture for a database system that you would like to experiment with, that's the kind of work that we would be willing to support now.
This is something that actually came through very clearly in the processing.

Offer the proposals that we received from our latest call, so there were a number of proposals really interesting, two of which we're going to fund if negotiation are successful that have to do with looking at the lowest part of the data analytics stack, right?
So most of you, I suppose, are working in software, but your software runs on some hardware and hardware is itself evolving in various ways.
So the question then is.
What kind of hardware evolution has or can be shown to have or can be made to have an impact on your data analytics capability.
So Costas was talking about earlier off the use of functional languages for data parallelization, but you can do data parallelization at the level of hardware.
So there are circuits like field programmable gate arrays that allow you to paralyze things all the way to the level of hardware.
So here we are not asking specifically for you to develop any specific solutions, so we are asking for in Group of competent people to help us understand what is the shape of the problem.
So we would like to understand if there is space for European researchers and companies to working on the hardware optimization of their data analytics processes.
So if you know anyone who is working in hardware or if you are somebody who works in hardware.
And has an interest in data analytics.
We would like to hear from you.

And so again, the problem here is not just how to squeeze every last bit of optimization from such systems, but also how to make them usable, because again, there are people who think and dream in hardware, but most programmers don't.
So how do you manage to allow for these optimizations for these optimizations to also be easy to program?
So sometimes there is a need.
For building programming environment where a person who is not necessarily a hardware expert would be able to take advantage of those optimizations.
Another interesting point of reflection that we are asking for.
Again, this is not about building any particular system or developing software, but it.
About doing some conceptual work has to do with what you could call data externalities.
So what is the next analogy?
Well, mixed reality is something that is the result of somebody's activities, which has an effect on the activities of somebody else, positive or negative.
So if I am a factory and I produce a certain product, and in the process I emit a certain kind of chemical in the atmosphere.
I have a negative externality on the persons who are living downwind.
Because yes, my first point of business is to produce my product, but in the process of doing so I do other things that damage people.
Positive externality is a situation where I do things that I don't necessarily mean to do, but end up benefiting something.
So what are what are the positive and negative externalities that we as Europe should care about?
So we talked about some of them in the process of yesterday's presentation.

So sometimes you have organizations that have a specific object of their business, but in the process of carrying out their business, they also produce data they don't necessarily need for themselves that could be used for somebody else.
So if you are a florist, for example, your job is to sell Flowers and move them from your shop to the person who is ordered the Flowers.
But in the process of doing so, perhaps you have a delivery van that is fitted with sensors that collects information about traffic or other things that are happening in the city.
So you need these data to optimize your flower delivery operations, but somebody else might also be interested in those data and use them for purposes that you don't even know about.
So being able to make the so called data exhaust available for others to use.
At whatever condition you choose, you can be generous and decide to share your data for free.
You could decide that the data that you collect in the process of delivering Flowers is actually a new product that you're also selling that somehow amortizes the costs of your flower delivery.
So that's an example of a positive externality.
So we are asking for your help to help us identify what are the win win situations where.
One part is producing or processing data causes somebody else to become more efficient at whatever they're doing.
These could be two different stages in a data analytics process.
Could be somebody producing data and somebody else using it.
Anything else that you can think of so you would like to have a broad spectrum of idea of what the design space for making positive effect spread happen.
Now there is on the downside, very clear case.
Of negative externalities, so this has to do, and again we talked about this yesterday a little bit.
This has to do with the what happens when so much data become available that certain inferences can be made about individuals.
So there is a very famous result that shows that in the United States, 87% of the residents of the United States.
Can be uniquely identified by their date of birth by the ZIP code and by the agenda.

So what that means is that if you have a database and you anonymize it and you just give me a list of records about individuals that contains those three bits of information, there is an 87% chance that I will be able to re identify those individuals.
Now, if you think about it.

The more data becomes available, the easier it is to re identify individuals, because it's like a puzzle, so the more pieces of the puzzle are already in place, the easier it becomes to identify where to place the remaining pieces.
So the question then is, so this is a problem that is rather similar in structure to the problem of environment pollution or global warming, so you have a situation.
Where a number of actors are collectively generating a potentially dangerous situation without any one of them being individually responsible for the final result.
So this is a really serious problem, and again this is the stage where we have no solution to indicate an it's important.
However, there we start reflecting on this in a rather structure memory, so if you have if you are an economist.
Tagra for or anyone who has any idea to propose on how to even conceptualize and investigate this problem, we want to hear from you.
We would like to hear a proposal on what kind of properties should be studied in order for us to address this particular problem, so repeating.
So this is about the effect that data activities have on others on those who are not carrying out those activities, whether they be positive or negative.
This is not about building any kind of software.
It is about creating a conceptual space of possibilities that need to be investigated.
So if given a map so the best possible result that we would expect from this is a study that says, well, if you have.
If you want to induce this kind of possible spillover effects for data activity, this is the kind of incentives that you would have to put in place.

Or Conversely, if you're worried about certain kind of things happening that violate privacy as a result of that activity, these are the kind of things that you have to put in place to make it difficult or impossible for them to help.
OK, so here.
Again.
So now we talked about large volumes of UN.
OK, so so this has to do with.
This is a different theme, so we did yesterday and today we've seen a lot of examples of open data being made available from scientists.
So for example there are now very large web pros available on various places from volunteers.
So good example is open St Maps from administrations local national international.
So this has happened at a scale that it was in fact even hard to predict, even just two or three years ago.
However, the reuse of these datasets does not seem to have kept pace with the availability of data.
So what is the bottleneck?
Well, So what we're trying to do in the next year, the last year of FP 7 is to essentially create an in.
Armand, where those constraints are being removed.
So if the reason why people do not develop applications based on data is be cause, they can't always obtain the data they need.
We would like to create an environment where that's taken care of for them.
If their problem is that the data they would like to use is not clean or is not link, we would like to create an environment where the cleaning and linking.
He's taken care of for them.

If their problem is that once they have an idea they don't find it easy to create, turn it into an actual product or business because they don't have the right connection with markets or with additional fund forms of funding.
We would like to create an environment that would take care of the problem for them or help them take care of the problem.
So this environment will be designed in such a way that he should be allowed.
It should be possible for small and medium enterprises too.
Experiment in very short cycles and use the best technology that we have available in Europe for very concrete applications.
So the idea then is to.

So going back actually to this slide is, so do to essentially set up a group of people that will act as an incubator and then will invite small and medium enterprises to come and work in this incubator, taking care of all the problems that I described before 1 aspect that is not on this slide that is really important is that this environment is also expected to act as a ambassador with.
Administrations from Member states.
So example you and your cousin have a working in the garage.
Have an excellent idea of what you would do if transportation data for a specific city where available, but the city does not make this data available.
So then the incubators job would then be you tell them well, I would like to have this data.
I know that in principle it should be available so the core team of the incubator would then.
Go and talk to your city and say well, is it possible to obtain these data and if it is not possible, what's the What's the problem?
So maybe we can help you publish this data.
Maybe you know the Transportation Department of your city is very busy, doesn't have the time.
Maybe they don't have the technical know how.
So one of the goals of the core personnel is incubator would be to be parachuted into the whole city and try to solve that date availability problem for you.

So and in so doing, there's a positive spillover that if they do their job right when they leave your city now knows how to publish certain forms of data, so perhaps they will be able to take care of their next.
OK, so there will be also support for developing software.
Components for data out.
Again, what does it take so?
Is there anything that can be done to make it easier to publish data so some of these work is happening in some of our existing projects?

So for example, the LD 2 project has this is one of its central goals, but maybe there are other aspects that are equally important, so not everything necessarily needs to be in RDF format, but maybe there are certain types of data that need to surface in different formats and maybe there is a need for tools to help you do that efficiently.
So what does it take to LinkedIn various forms?

Again, RDF is different Matic case, but they need their other types of links and other types of data that also needs to be linked so you imagine you know the equivalent of Google Refine in whatever domain it is that you need to get data to be linked across datasets if need be, what does it make to make applications data where so and what does it take?
Also, especially to support to multiple platforms so.
One of the very big trends of the last few years is the phenomenal growth of mobile devices.
So I think that most of the applications that I've seen discussed yesterday and today have a very clear desktop orientation.
But perhaps there are environments where it is important that data be part of an application solution that need to work in a mobile environment.
So what does it take to make that happen?
So if you have any ideas along those lines, we're happy to support you with that idea.
So for language technologies, again the same.
Happens at the same.

The same concept applies, and again the orientation is not so much to do groundbreaking and completely novel research as much as to take whatever interesting results exist and help them move towards industrial products with a special emphasis on performance, robustness and coverage.
But also things like integration of datasets, experimentation, and very importantly usability and also try to identify what is implausible exploitation path.
For these technologies.
So my finest line is.
So this I can announce officially.
So although we don't have an official work program yet, we do have an official event to talk about the work program.
So on the 26th and 27th of September in worship, we're going to hold a networking for European information and communication technologies.
So what this basically means, essentially a very large, so it 2 important things will have two things that may be useful to you.
So there will be much much more detailed presentation of all aspects of our work program.
So today I gave you an overview of what this specific corner, the specific data corner of the work program looks like in war show.

You will hear the entire work program, so there will be parallel sessions where whatever you're interested in you will be able to get a completely exhaustive explanation of what is being asked, why and with what purpose.
Another thing that these events.
Might be useful for is for you to make connections, so perhaps you have 1/2 of a good idea and somebody else so you don't know yet has the other half.
So if you both attend the event, there may be a chance that you'll meet up and come together with one complete good idea, so I'll be around at the end of so.
I'll take questions now, but will certainly be around until later, so if anyone has any questions they want to ask that does not involve knowing the exact text to the work program.
Does not involve knowing exact dates and exact budget.
I'll be happy to answer them.
Thank you.
So the question was.
Big Data is not for everyone, so there are data dependent applications that do not require necessarily big data.
And if you drop it on them, they wouldn't necessarily want to do so.
There needs to be a mechanism for being able to extract from a large data repository the minimum set that you actually need for setting up an application which are asking.
OK, well, so as such it is a big data problem in the sense that once it gets the application, it's no longer big data.
But the problem starts.
With Big Data as an input, so the answer would say yes.
Necessarily connect, so it's it's an interesting observation and problem, but I wouldn't necessarily connected as to the issue of the externalities that I was talking about before.
You are talking about that incubator or helping open up the data.
I'm very interested in because we ran into the problem.
Is there part of the children's or is that a separate program and I'm sorry I didn't get the question.
Is that part of what?
News, or is that a separate program?
Are you just sitting there right?
So this is the part where I cannot really give you the answer that you deserve, because this requires me to go into the actual specifics of the work program so.
Wait until mid July and then everything will be much much clearer.
Yes, sorry, so perhaps sorry as a provisional answer to you.
Maybe I could tell you the second best thing I can do for you is to point you at the Open Data Institute that Niger Shadow was talking about this morning.
Take a look at their business plan and you know get a sense in general of how such an incubator might work.

About doing some conceptual work has to do with what you could call data externalities.
So what is the next analogy?
Well, mixed reality is something that is the result of somebody's activities, which has an effect on the activities of somebody else, positive or negative.
So if I am a factory and I produce a certain product, and in the process I emit a certain kind of chemical in the atmosphere.
I have a negative externality on the persons who are living downwind.
Because yes, my first point of business is to produce my product, but in the process of doing so I do other things that damage people.
Positive externality is a situation where I do things that I don't necessarily mean to do, but end up benefiting something.
So what are what are the positive and negative externalities that we as Europe should care about?
So we talked about some of them in the process of yesterday's presentation.

So sometimes you have organizations that have a specific object of their business, but in the process of carrying out their business, they also produce data they don't necessarily need for themselves that could be used for somebody else.
So if you are a florist, for example, your job is to sell Flowers and move them from your shop to the person who is ordered the Flowers.
But in the process of doing so, perhaps you have a delivery van that is fitted with sensors that collects information about traffic or other things that are happening in the city.
So you need these data to optimize your flower delivery operations, but somebody else might also be interested in those data and use them for purposes that you don't even know about.
So being able to make the so called data exhaust available for others to use.
At whatever condition you choose, you can be generous and decide to share your data for free.
You could decide that the data that you collect in the process of delivering Flowers is actually a new product that you're also selling that somehow amortizes the costs of your flower delivery.
So that's an example of a positive externality.
So we are asking for your help to help us identify what are the win win situations where.
One part is producing or processing data causes somebody else to become more efficient at whatever they're doing.
These could be two different stages in a data analytics process.
Could be somebody producing data and somebody else using it.
Anything else that you can think of so you would like to have a broad spectrum of idea of what the design space for making positive effect spread happen.
Now there is on the downside, very clear case.
Of negative externalities, so this has to do, and again we talked about this yesterday a little bit.
This has to do with the what happens when so much data become available that certain inferences can be made about individuals.
So there is a very famous result that shows that in the United States, 87% of the residents of the United States.
Can be uniquely identified by their date of birth by the ZIP code and by the agenda.

So what that means is that if you have a database and you anonymize it and you just give me a list of records about individuals that contains those three bits of information, there is an 87% chance that I will be able to re identify those individuals.
Now, if you think about it.

The more data becomes available, the easier it is to re identify individuals, because it's like a puzzle, so the more pieces of the puzzle are already in place, the easier it becomes to identify where to place the remaining pieces.
So the question then is, so this is a problem that is rather similar in structure to the problem of environment pollution or global warming, so you have a situation.
Where a number of actors are collectively generating a potentially dangerous situation without any one of them being individually responsible for the final result.
So this is a really serious problem, and again this is the stage where we have no solution to indicate an it's important.
